an11.4:1.1.pli: Tatra kho āyasmā sāriputto bhikkhū āmantesi:
an11.4:1.1.eng: There Venerable Sāriputta addressed the mendicants:

an11.4:1.3.pli: “Āvuso”ti kho te bhikkhū āyasmato sāriputtassa paccassosuṃ.

an11.4:2.1.eng: “An unethical person, who lacks ethics, has destroyed a vital condition for not having regrets.

an11.4:2.2.pli: avippaṭisāre asati avippaṭisāravipannassa hatūpanisaṃ hoti pāmojjaṃ,
an11.4:2.2.eng: When there are regrets, one who has regrets has destroyed a vital condition for joy.

an11.4:2.3.pli: pāmojje asati pāmojjavipannassa hatūpanisā hoti pīti,
an11.4:2.3.eng: When there is no joy, one who lacks joy has destroyed a vital condition for rapture.

an11.4:2.4.pli: pītiyā asati pītivipannassa hatūpanisā hoti passaddhi,
an11.4:2.4.eng: When there is no rapture, one who lacks rapture has destroyed a vital condition for tranquility.

an11.4:2.5.pli: passaddhiyā asati passaddhivipannassa hatūpanisaṃ hoti sukhaṃ,
an11.4:2.5.eng: When there is no tranquility, one who lacks tranquility has destroyed a vital condition for bliss.

an11.4:2.6.pli: sukhe asati sukhavipannassa hatūpaniso hoti sammāsamādhi,
an11.4:2.6.eng: When there is no bliss, one who lacks bliss has destroyed a vital condition for right immersion.

an11.4:2.7.pli: sammāsamādhimhi asati sammāsamādhivipannassa hatūpanisaṃ hoti yathābhūtañāṇadassanaṃ,
an11.4:2.7.eng: When there is no right immersion, one who lacks right immersion has destroyed a vital condition for true knowledge and vision.

an11.4:2.8.pli: yathābhūtañāṇadassane asati yathābhūtañāṇadassanavipannassa hatūpanisā hoti nibbidā,
an11.4:2.8.eng: When there is no true knowledge and vision, one who lacks true knowledge and vision has destroyed a vital condition for disillusionment.

an11.4:2.9.pli: nibbidāya asati nibbidāvipannassa hatūpaniso hoti virāgo,
an11.4:2.9.eng: When there is no disillusionment, one who lacks disillusionment has destroyed a vital condition for dispassion.

an11.4:2.10.pli: virāge asati virāgavipannassa hatūpanisaṃ hoti vimuttiñāṇadassanaṃ.
an11.4:2.10.eng: When there is no dispassion, one who lacks dispassion has destroyed a vital condition for knowledge and vision of freedom.

an11.4:3.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, āvuso, rukkho sākhāpalāsavipanno. Tassa papaṭikāpi na pāripūriṃ gacchati, tacopi … pheggupi … sāropi na pāripūriṃ gacchati.
an11.4:3.1.eng: Suppose there was a tree that lacked branches and foliage. Its shoots, bark, softwood, and heartwood would not grow to fullness.

an11.4:3.2.pli: Evamevaṃ kho, āvuso, dussīlassa sīlavipannassa hatūpaniso hoti avippaṭisāro,
an11.4:3.2.eng: In the same way, an unethical person, who lacks ethics, has destroyed a vital condition for having no regrets.

an11.4:3.3.pli: avippaṭisāre asati avippaṭisāravipannassa hatūpanisaṃ hoti pāmojjaṃ …pe…
an11.4:3.3.eng: When there are regrets, one who has regrets has destroyed a vital condition for joy. …

an11.4:3.4.eng: When there is dispassion, one who lacks dispassion has destroyed a vital condition for knowledge and vision of freedom.

an11.4:4.1.pli: Sīlavato, āvuso, sīlasampannassa upanisasampanno hoti avippaṭisāro,
an11.4:4.1.eng: An ethical person, who has fulfilled ethics, has fulfilled a vital condition for not having regrets.

an11.4:4.2.pli: avippaṭisāre sati avippaṭisārasampannassa upanisasampannaṃ hoti pāmojjaṃ,
an11.4:4.2.eng: When there are no regrets, one who has no regrets has fulfilled a vital condition for joy.

an11.4:4.3.pli: pāmojje sati pāmojjasampannassa upanisasampannā hoti pīti,
an11.4:4.3.eng: When there is joy, one who has fulfilled joy has fulfilled a vital condition for rapture.

an11.4:4.4.pli: pītiyā sati pītisampannassa upanisasampannā hoti passaddhi,
an11.4:4.4.eng: When there is rapture, one who has fulfilled rapture has fulfilled a vital condition for tranquility.

an11.4:4.5.pli: passaddhiyā sati passaddhisampannassa upanisasampannaṃ hoti sukhaṃ,
an11.4:4.5.eng: When there is tranquility, one who has fulfilled tranquility has fulfilled a vital condition for bliss.

an11.4:4.6.pli: sukhe sati sukhasampannassa upanisasampanno hoti sammāsamādhi,
an11.4:4.6.eng: When there is bliss, one who has fulfilled bliss has fulfilled a vital condition for right immersion.

an11.4:4.7.pli: sammāsamādhimhi sati sammāsamādhisampannassa upanisasampannaṃ hoti yathābhūtañāṇadassanaṃ,
an11.4:4.7.eng: When there is right immersion, one who has fulfilled right immersion has fulfilled a vital condition for true knowledge and vision.

an11.4:4.8.pli: yathābhūtañāṇadassane sati yathābhūtañāṇadassanasampannassa upanisasampannā hoti nibbidā,
an11.4:4.8.eng: When there is true knowledge and vision, one who has fulfilled true knowledge and vision has fulfilled a vital condition for disillusionment.

an11.4:4.9.pli: nibbidāya sati nibbidāsampannassa upanisasampanno hoti virāgo,
an11.4:4.9.eng: When there is disillusionment, one who has fulfilled disillusionment has fulfilled a vital condition for dispassion.

an11.4:4.10.pli: virāge sati virāgasampannassa upanisasampannaṃ hoti vimuttiñāṇadassanaṃ.
an11.4:4.10.eng: When there is dispassion, one who has fulfilled dispassion has fulfilled a vital condition for knowledge and vision of freedom.

an11.4:5.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, āvuso, rukkho sākhāpalāsasampanno. Tassa papaṭikāpi pāripūriṃ gacchati, tacopi … pheggupi … sāropi pāripūriṃ gacchati.
an11.4:5.1.eng: Suppose there was a tree that was complete with branches and foliage. Its shoots, bark, softwood, and heartwood would grow to fullness.

an11.4:5.2.pli: Evamevaṃ kho, āvuso, sīlavato sīlasampannassa upanisasampanno hoti avippaṭisāro,
an11.4:5.2.eng: In the same way, an ethical person, who has fulfilled ethics, has fulfilled a vital condition for not having regrets.

an11.4:5.3.pli: avippaṭisāre sati avippaṭisārasampannassa upanisasampannaṃ hoti pāmojjaṃ …pe…
an11.4:5.3.eng: When there are no regrets, one who has no regrets has fulfilled a vital condition for joy. …

an11.4:5.4.eng: When there is dispassion, one who has fulfilled dispassion has fulfilled a vital condition for knowledge and vision of freedom.”

an11.406-453:0.4.eng: Untitled Discourses on Thoughts About Sights, Etc.

an11.454-501:0.4.eng: Untitled Discourses on Considerations Regarding Sights, Etc.

an11.454-501:1.7.eng: meditate observing impermanence in considerations about ideas …

an11.5:4.2.eng: In the same way, an ethical person, who has fulfilled ethics, has fulfilled a vital condition for not having regrets.

an11.5:4.3.pli: avippaṭisāre sati avippaṭisārasampannassa upanisasampannaṃ hoti pāmojjaṃ …pe…

an11.502-981:0.4.eng: Untitled Discourses on the Eye, Etc.

an11.502-981:1.1.pli: Ekādasahi, bhikkhave, aṅgehi samannāgato gopālako bhabbo gogaṇaṃ pariharituṃ phātikātuṃ.
an11.502-981:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, a cowherd with eleven factors can maintain and expand a herd of cattle.

an11.502-981:1.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, gopālako rūpaññū hoti… pe…
an11.502-981:1.3.eng: It’s when a cowherd knows form …

an11.502-981:2.1.pli: Evameva kho, bhikkhave, ekādasahi dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu bhabbo cakkhusmiṃ aniccānupassī viharituṃ…
an11.502-981:2.1.eng: In the same way, a mendicant with eleven qualities can meditate observing impermanence in the eye …

an11.6:1.1.pli: “Yo so, bhikkhave, bhikkhu akkosako paribhāsako ariyūpavādo sabrahmacārīnaṃ, ṭhānametaṃ avakāso yaṃ so ekādasannaṃ byasanānaṃ aññataraṃ byasanaṃ nigaccheyya.
an11.6:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, any mendicant who abuses and insults their spiritual companions, denouncing the noble ones, will, without a doubt, fall into one or other of these eleven disasters.

an11.6:2.3.eng: What they have achieved falls away.

an11.6:2.4.eng: They don’t refine their good qualities.

an11.6:2.5.eng: Or they overestimate their good qualities.

an11.6:2.6.eng: Or they lead the spiritual life dissatisfied.

an11.6:2.7.eng: Or they commit a corrupt offense.

an11.6:2.8.eng: Or they resign the training and return to a lesser life.

an11.6:2.9.eng: Or they contract a severe illness.

an11.6:2.10.eng: Or they go mad or lose their mind.

an11.6:2.11.eng: They feel lost when they die.

an11.6:2.12.pli: kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā apāyaṃ duggatiṃ vinipātaṃ nirayaṃ upapajjati—
an11.6:2.12.eng: And when their body breaks up, after death, they are reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.

an11.6:2.13.pli: yo so, bhikkhave, bhikkhu akkosako paribhāsako ariyūpavādo sabrahmacārīnaṃ, ṭhānametaṃ avakāso yaṃ so imesaṃ ekādasannaṃ byasanānaṃ aññataraṃ byasanaṃ nigaccheyya.
an11.6:2.13.eng: Any mendicant who abuses and insults their spiritual companions, denouncing the noble ones, will, without a doubt, fall into one or other of these eleven disasters.

an11.6:3.1.pli: Yo so, bhikkhave, bhikkhu akkosako paribhāsako ariyūpavādo sabrahmacārīnaṃ, aṭṭhānametaṃ anavakāso yaṃ so ekādasannaṃ byasanānaṃ aññataraṃ byasanaṃ na nigaccheyya.
an11.6:3.1.eng: Any mendicant who does not abuse and insult their spiritual companions, denouncing the noble ones, will, without a doubt, not fall into one or other of these eleven disasters.

an11.6:4.3.eng: What they have achieved falls away.

an11.6:4.4.eng: They don’t refine their good qualities.

an11.6:4.6.eng: Or they lead the spiritual life dissatisfied.

an11.6:4.7.eng: Or they commit one of the corrupt offenses.

an11.6:4.8.eng: Or they resign the training and return to a lesser life.

an11.6:4.9.eng: Or they contract a severe illness.

an11.6:4.10.eng: Or they go mad or lose their mind.

an11.6:4.11.eng: They feel lost when they die.

an11.6:4.12.pli: kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā apāyaṃ duggatiṃ vinipātaṃ nirayaṃ upapajjati—
an11.6:4.12.eng: And when their body breaks up, after death, they are reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.

an11.6:4.13.pli: yo so, bhikkhave, bhikkhu akkosako paribhāsako ariyūpavādo sabrahmacārīnaṃ, aṭṭhānametaṃ anavakāso yaṃ so imesaṃ ekādasannaṃ byasanānaṃ aññataraṃ byasanaṃ na nigaccheyyā”ti.
an11.6:4.13.eng: Any mendicant who does not abuse and insult their spiritual companions, denouncing the noble ones, will, without a doubt, not fall into one or other of these eleven disasters.”

an11.7:1.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā ānando yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā ānando bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
an11.7:1.1.eng: Then Venerable Ānanda went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him:

an11.7:2.1.pli: “Siyā nu kho, bhante, bhikkhuno tathārūpo samādhipaṭilābho yathā neva pathaviyaṃ pathavisaññī assa, na āpasmiṃ āposaññī assa, na tejasmiṃ tejosaññī assa, na vāyasmiṃ vāyosaññī assa, na ākāsānañcāyatane ākāsānañcāyatanasaññī assa, na viññāṇañcāyatane viññāṇañcāyatanasaññī assa, na ākiñcaññāyatane ākiñcaññāyatanasaññī assa, na nevasaññānāsaññāyatane nevasaññānāsaññāyatanasaññī assa, na idhaloke idhalokasaññī assa, na paraloke paralokasaññī assa, yampidaṃ diṭṭhaṃ sutaṃ mutaṃ viññātaṃ pattaṃ pariyesitaṃ anuvicaritaṃ manasā, tatrāpi na saññī assa; saññī ca pana assā”ti?
an11.7:2.1.eng: “Could it be, sir, that a mendicant might gain a state of immersion like this? They wouldn’t perceive earth in earth, water in water, fire in fire, or air in air. And they wouldn’t perceive the dimension of infinite space in the dimension of infinite space, the dimension of infinite consciousness in the dimension of infinite consciousness, the dimension of nothingness in the dimension of nothingness, or the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception in the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception. They wouldn’t perceive this world in this world, or the other world in the other world. And they wouldn’t perceive what is seen, heard, thought, known, attained, sought, or explored by the mind. And yet they would still perceive.”

an11.7:3.1.pli: “Siyā, ānanda, bhikkhuno tathārūpo samādhipaṭilābho yathā neva pathaviyaṃ pathavisaññī assa, na āpasmiṃ āposaññī assa, na tejasmiṃ tejosaññī assa, na vāyasmiṃ vāyosaññī assa, na ākāsānañcāyatane ākāsānañcāyatanasaññī assa, na viññāṇañcāyatane viññāṇañcāyatanasaññī assa, na ākiñcaññāyatane ākiñcaññāyatanasaññī assa, na nevasaññānāsaññāyatane nevasaññānāsaññāyatanasaññī assa, na idhaloke idhalokasaññī assa, na paraloke paralokasaññī assa, yampidaṃ diṭṭhaṃ sutaṃ mutaṃ viññātaṃ pattaṃ pariyesitaṃ anuvicaritaṃ manasā, tatrāpi na saññī assa; saññī ca pana assā”ti.
an11.7:3.1.eng: “It could be, Ānanda, that a mendicant might gain a state of immersion like this. They wouldn’t perceive earth in earth, water in water, fire in fire, or air in air. And they wouldn’t perceive the dimension of infinite space in the dimension of infinite space, the dimension of infinite consciousness in the dimension of infinite consciousness, the dimension of nothingness in the dimension of nothingness, or the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception in the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception. They wouldn’t perceive this world in this world, or the other world in the other world. And they wouldn’t perceive what is seen, heard, thought, known, attained, sought, or explored by the mind. And yet they would still perceive.”

an11.7:4.1.pli: “Yathā kathaṃ pana, bhante, siyā bhikkhuno tathārūpo samādhipaṭilābho yathā neva pathaviyaṃ pathavisaññī assa, na āpasmiṃ āposaññī assa, na tejasmiṃ tejosaññī assa, na vāyasmiṃ vāyosaññī assa, na ākāsānañcāyatane ākāsānañcāyatanasaññī assa, na viññāṇañcāyatane viññāṇañcāyatanasaññī assa, na ākiñcaññāyatane ākiñcaññāyatanasaññī assa, na nevasaññānāsaññāyatane nevasaññānāsaññāyatanasaññī assa, na idhaloke idhalokasaññī assa, na paraloke paralokasaññī assa, yampidaṃ diṭṭhaṃ sutaṃ mutaṃ viññātaṃ pattaṃ pariyesitaṃ anuvicaritaṃ manasā, tatrāpi na saññī assa, saññī ca pana assā”ti.

an11.7:5.2.pli: ‘etaṃ santaṃ etaṃ paṇītaṃ, yadidaṃ sabbasaṅkhārasamatho sabbūpadhipaṭinissaggo taṇhākkhayo virāgo nirodho nibbānan’ti.
an11.7:5.2.eng: ‘This is peaceful; this is sublime—that is, the stilling of all activities, the letting go of all attachments, the ending of craving, fading away, cessation, extinguishment.’

an11.7:5.3.pli: Evaṃ kho, ānanda, siyā bhikkhuno tathārūpo samādhipaṭilābho yathā neva pathaviyaṃ pathavisaññī assa, na āpasmiṃ āposaññī assa, na tejasmiṃ tejosaññī assa, na vāyasmiṃ vāyosaññī assa, na ākāsānañcāyatane ākāsānañcāyatanasaññī assa, na viññāṇañcāyatane viññāṇañcāyatanasaññī assa, na ākiñcaññāyatane ākiñcaññāyatanasaññī assa, na nevasaññānāsaññāyatane nevasaññānāsaññāyatanasaññī assa, na idhaloke idhalokasaññī assa, na paraloke paralokasaññī assa, yampidaṃ diṭṭhaṃ sutaṃ mutaṃ viññātaṃ pattaṃ pariyesitaṃ anuvicaritaṃ manasā, tatrāpi na saññī assa, saññī ca pana assā”ti.
an11.7:5.3.eng: That’s how a mendicant might gain a state of immersion like this. They wouldn’t perceive earth in earth, water in water, fire in fire, or air in air. And they wouldn’t perceive the dimension of infinite space in the dimension of infinite space, the dimension of infinite consciousness in the dimension of infinite consciousness, the dimension of nothingness in the dimension of nothingness, or the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception in the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception. They wouldn’t perceive this world in this world, or the other world in the other world. And they wouldn’t perceive what is seen, heard, thought, known, attained, sought, or explored by the mind. And yet they would still perceive.”

an11.7:6.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā ānando bhagavato bhāsitaṃ abhinanditvā anumoditvā uṭṭhāyāsanā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṃ katvā yenāyasmā sāriputto tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmatā sāriputtena saddhiṃ sammodi.
an11.7:6.1.eng: And then Ānanda approved and agreed with what the Buddha said. He got up from his seat, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on his right. Then he went up to Venerable Sāriputta, and exchanged greetings with him.

an11.7:6.2.pli: Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā ānando āyasmantaṃ sāriputtaṃ etadavoca:
an11.7:6.2.eng: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side and said to Sāriputta:

an11.7:7.1.pli: “Siyā nu kho, āvuso sāriputta, bhikkhuno tathārūpo samādhipaṭilābho yathā neva pathaviyaṃ pathavisaññī assa …pe… yampidaṃ diṭṭhaṃ sutaṃ mutaṃ viññātaṃ pattaṃ pariyesitaṃ anuvicaritaṃ manasā, tatrāpi na saññī assa, saññī pana assā”ti.
an11.7:7.1.eng: “Could it be, reverend Sāriputta, that a mendicant might gain a state of immersion like this? They wouldn’t perceive earth in earth … And they wouldn’t perceive what is seen, heard, thought, known, attained, sought, or explored by the mind. And yet they would still perceive.”

an11.7:7.2.pli: “Siyā, āvuso ānanda, bhikkhuno tathārūpo samādhipaṭilābho yathā neva pathaviyaṃ pathavisaññī assa …pe… yampidaṃ diṭṭhaṃ sutaṃ mutaṃ viññātaṃ pattaṃ pariyesitaṃ anuvicaritaṃ manasā, tatrāpi na saññī assa, saññī ca pana assā”ti.

an11.7:8.1.pli: “Yathā kathaṃ panāvuso sāriputta, siyā bhikkhuno tathārūpo samādhipaṭilābho yathā neva pathaviyaṃ pathavisaññī assa …pe… yampidaṃ diṭṭhaṃ sutaṃ mutaṃ viññātaṃ pattaṃ pariyesitaṃ anuvicaritaṃ manasā, tatrāpi na saññī assa, saññī ca pana assā”ti?

an11.7:9.2.pli: ‘etaṃ santaṃ etaṃ paṇītaṃ, yadidaṃ sabbasaṅkhārasamatho sabbūpadhipaṭinissaggo taṇhākkhayo virāgo nirodho nibbānan’ti.
an11.7:9.2.eng: ‘This is peaceful; this is sublime—that is, the stilling of all activities, the letting go of all attachments, the ending of craving, fading away, cessation, extinguishment.’

an11.7:9.3.pli: Evaṃ kho, āvuso ānanda, siyā bhikkhuno tathārūpo samādhipaṭilābho yathā neva pathaviyaṃ pathavisaññī assa …pe… yampidaṃ diṭṭhaṃ sutaṃ mutaṃ viññātaṃ pattaṃ pariyesitaṃ anuvicaritaṃ manasā, tatrāpi na saññī assa, saññī ca pana assā”ti.
an11.7:9.3.eng: That’s how a mendicant might gain a state of immersion like this. They wouldn’t perceive earth in earth … And they wouldn’t perceive what is seen, heard, thought, known, attained, sought, or explored by the mind. And yet they would still perceive.”

an11.7:10.2.pli: Yatra hi nāma satthu ceva sāvakassa ca atthena attho byañjanena byañjanaṃ saṃsandissati samessati na viggayhissati, yadidaṃ aggapadasmiṃ.
an11.7:10.2.eng: How the meaning and the phrasing of the teacher and the disciple fit together and agree without conflict when it comes to the chief matter!

an11.7:10.3.pli: Idānāhaṃ, āvuso, bhagavantaṃ upasaṅkamitvā etamatthaṃ apucchiṃ.
an11.7:10.3.eng: Just now I went to the Buddha and asked him about this matter.

an11.7:10.4.pli: Bhagavāpi me etehi akkharehi etehi padehi etehi byañjanehi etamatthaṃ byākāsi, seyyathāpi āyasmā sāriputto.
an11.7:10.4.eng: And the Buddha explained it to me in this manner, with these words and phrases, just like Venerable Sāriputta.

an11.7:10.6.pli: Yatra hi nāma satthu ceva sāvakassa ca atthena attho byañjanena byañjanaṃ saṃsandissati samessati na viggayhissati, yadidaṃ aggapadasmin”ti.
an11.7:10.6.eng: How the meaning and the phrasing of the teacher and the disciple fit together and agree without conflict when it comes to the chief matter!”

an11.8:1.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā ānando yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā ānando bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
an11.8:1.1.eng: Then Venerable Ānanda went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him:

an11.8:2.1.pli: “Siyā nu kho, bhante, bhikkhuno tathārūpo samādhipaṭilābho yathā na cakkhuṃ manasi kareyya, na rūpaṃ manasi kareyya, na sotaṃ manasi kareyya, na saddaṃ manasi kareyya, na ghānaṃ manasi kareyya, na gandhaṃ manasi kareyya, na jivhaṃ manasi kareyya, na rasaṃ manasi kareyya, na kāyaṃ manasi kareyya, na phoṭṭhabbaṃ manasi kareyya, na pathaviṃ manasi kareyya, na āpaṃ manasi kareyya, na tejaṃ manasi kareyya, na vāyaṃ manasi kareyya, na ākāsānañcāyatanaṃ manasi kareyya, na viññāṇañcāyatanaṃ manasi kareyya, na ākiñcaññāyatanaṃ manasi kareyya, na nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaṃ manasi kareyya, na idhalokaṃ manasi kareyya, na paralokaṃ manasi kareyya, yampidaṃ diṭṭhaṃ sutaṃ mutaṃ viññātaṃ pattaṃ pariyesitaṃ anuvicaritaṃ manasā, tampi na manasi kareyya;
an11.8:2.1.eng: “Could it be, sir, that a mendicant might gain a state of immersion like this. They wouldn’t focus on the eye or sights, ear or sounds, nose or smells, tongue or tastes, or body or touches. They wouldn’t focus on earth in earth, water in water, fire in fire, or air in air. And they wouldn’t focus on the dimension of infinite space in the dimension of infinite space, the dimension of infinite consciousness in the dimension of infinite consciousness, the dimension of nothingness in the dimension of nothingness, or the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception in the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception. They wouldn’t focus on this world in this world, or the other world in the other world. And they wouldn’t focus on what is seen, heard, thought, known, attained, sought, or explored by the mind.

an11.8:3.1.pli: “Siyā, ānanda, bhikkhuno tathārūpo samādhipaṭilābho yathā na cakkhuṃ manasi kareyya, na rūpaṃ manasi kareyya, na sotaṃ manasi kareyya, na saddaṃ manasi kareyya, na ghānaṃ manasi kareyya, na gandhaṃ manasi kareyya, na jivhaṃ manasi kareyya, na rasaṃ manasi kareyya, na kāyaṃ manasi kareyya, na phoṭṭhabbaṃ manasi kareyya, na pathaviṃ manasi kareyya, na āpaṃ manasi kareyya, na tejaṃ manasi kareyya, na vāyaṃ manasi kareyya, na ākāsānañcāyatanaṃ manasi kareyya, na viññāṇañcāyatanaṃ manasi kareyya, na ākiñcaññāyatanaṃ manasi kareyya, na nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaṃ manasi kareyya, na idhalokaṃ manasi kareyya, na paralokaṃ manasi kareyya, yampidaṃ diṭṭhaṃ sutaṃ mutaṃ viññātaṃ pattaṃ pariyesitaṃ anuvicaritaṃ manasā, tampi na manasi kareyya;

an11.8:4.1.pli: “Yathā kathaṃ pana, bhante, siyā bhikkhuno tathārūpo samādhipaṭilābho yathā na cakkhuṃ manasi kareyya, na rūpaṃ manasi kareyya …pe…

an11.8:4.2.pli: yampidaṃ diṭṭhaṃ sutaṃ mutaṃ viññātaṃ pattaṃ pariyesitaṃ anuvicaritaṃ manasā, tampi na manasi kareyya;

an11.8:5.1.eng: “Ānanda, it’s when a mendicant focuses thus:

an11.8:5.2.pli: ‘etaṃ santaṃ etaṃ paṇītaṃ, yadidaṃ sabbasaṅkhārasamatho sabbūpadhipaṭinissaggo taṇhākkhayo virāgo nirodho nibbānan’ti.
an11.8:5.2.eng: ‘This is peaceful; this is sublime—that is, the stilling of all activities, the letting go of all attachments, the ending of craving, fading away, cessation, extinguishment.’

an11.8:5.3.pli: Evaṃ kho, ānanda, siyā bhikkhuno tathārūpo samādhipaṭilābho yathā na cakkhuṃ manasi kareyya, na rūpaṃ manasi kareyya …pe…
an11.8:5.3.eng: That’s how a mendicant might gain a state of immersion like this. They wouldn’t focus on the eye or sights, ear or sounds, nose or smells, tongue or tastes, or body or touches. …

an11.8:5.4.pli: yampidaṃ diṭṭhaṃ sutaṃ mutaṃ viññātaṃ pattaṃ pariyesitaṃ anuvicaritaṃ manasā, tampi na manasi kareyya;
an11.8:5.4.eng: And they wouldn’t focus on what is seen, heard, thought, known, attained, sought, or explored by the mind.
